required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Safety and Efficacy Study of Enzalutamide Versus Bicalutamide in Men With Prostate Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Strive: A Multicenter Phase 2, Randomized, Double-blind, Efficacy And Safety Study Of Enzalutamide Vs. Bicalutamide In Men With Prostate Cancer Who Have Failed Primary Androgen Deprivation Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of enzalutamide vs bicalutamide in asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic patients with prostate cancer who have disease progression despite primary androgen deprivation therapy.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study is a multicenter phase 2, randomized, double-blind, efficacy and safety study of enzalutamide (160 mg/day) vs. bicalutamide (50 mg/day) in patients with recurrent prostate cancer who have serologic and/or radiographic disease progression despite primary androgen deprivation therapy.
Throughout the study, safety and tolerability will be assessed by the recording of adverse events, monitoring of vital signs, physical examinations, and safety laboratory evaluations.
Following study unblinding, study patients receiving enzalutamide or bicalutamide at the time of unblinding and qualifying patients randomized to bicalutamide who discontinued prior to unblinding will be offered the opportunity to receive open label enzalutamide treatment.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
primary_outcome.description: PFS was defined as time from randomization to earliest objective evidence of prostate specific-antigen (PSA) progression, radiographic progression, or death on study. PSA progression was defined as ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir and was to be confirmed by a second consecutive assessment. Radiographic progression in bone was based on The Prostate Cancer Clinical Trials Working Group (PCWG2) guidelines defined as at least 2 new lesions on bone scan. Radiographic progression in soft tissue on Computerized Tomography/Magnetic Resonance Imaging (CT/MRI) was based on Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST 1.1). CT/MRI and bone scans were read locally by the same radiologist (or nuclear medicine physician for interpretation of bone scans) whenever possible. Participants not known to have had a PFS event at the time of the analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last assessment.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
secondary_outcome.description: PSA progression was defined as ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir and was to be confirmed by a second consecutive assessment at least 3 weeks later. Participants not known to have had PSA progression were censored at the date of last PSA assessment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PSA Response ≥ 50%
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
secondary_outcome.description: PSA response was defined as a reduction in PSA of at least 50% from baseline at any postbaseline assessment confirmed by a second PSA assessment at least 3 weeks later.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of radiographic PFS was defined as the time from randomization to the earliest objective evidence of radiographic disease progression or death on study and was to be evaluated for participants with metastatic disease at study entry. Radiographic disease progression in bone was based on PCWG2 guidelines defined as at least 2 new lesions on bone scan. Radiographic disease progression in soft tissue on CT/MRI was based on RECIST 1.1. CT/MRI and bone scans were read locally by the same radiologist (or nuclear medicine physician for interpretation of bone scans) whenever possible. Participants not known to have had radiographic progression at the time of analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last radiographic assessment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life: Time to Degradation of Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Prostate (FACT-P)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
secondary_outcome.description: The FACT-P is a multidimensional, self-reported quality of life instrument consisting of 27 core items that assess patient function in 4 domains: physical, social/family, emotional, and functional well-being, and supplemented by 12 site-specific items to assess for prostate-related symptoms. Each item is rated on a 0 to 4 Likert-type scale, and then combined to produce subscale scores for each domain, as well as a global quality of life score (0 to 156) with higher scores representing better quality of life. Time to degradation of FACT-P was defined as the time from randomization to first assessment with at least a 10-point decrease from baseline in the global FACT-P score for each participant. Participants with no score degradation at the time of analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last assessment showing no degradation.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
secondary_outcome.description: Best overall soft tissue response is defined as partial response (PR) or complete response (CR) while on study treatment based on investigator assessment of target, nontarget, and new lesions using RECIST 1.1. Only participants in the metastatic population with measurable soft tissue disease (at least 1 target lesion identified per RECIST 1.1) at screening were included in the analysis. All percentages are based on number of participants with metastatic and measurable soft tissue disease at screening in each treatment group.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Adverse Event (AE)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose of study drug up to 30 days after last dose of study drug. Median duration of the AE reporting period was 15.2 months in the enzalutamide arm and 9.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants received bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

participants_list.participants: Indicates participants continuing to receive treatment as of 09 February 2015.
Indicates participants continuing to receive treatment as of 09 February 2015.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants received bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Progression Free Survival (PFS)
outcome.description: PFS was defined as time from randomization to earliest objective evidence of prostate specific-antigen (PSA) progression, radiographic progression, or death on study. PSA progression was defined as ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir and was to be confirmed by a second consecutive assessment. Radiographic progression in bone was based on The Prostate Cancer Clinical Trials Working Group (PCWG2) guidelines defined as at least 2 new lesions on bone scan. Radiographic progression in soft tissue on Computerized Tomography/Magnetic Resonance Imaging (CT/MRI) was based on Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST 1.1). CT/MRI and bone scans were read locally by the same radiologist (or nuclear medicine physician for interpretation of bone scans) whenever possible. Participants not known to have had a PFS event at the time of the analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last assessment.
outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
outcome.population: Intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

measure.title: Progression Free Survival (PFS)
measure.description: PFS was defined as time from randomization to earliest objective evidence of prostate specific-antigen (PSA) progression, radiographic progression, or death on study. PSA progression was defined as ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir and was to be confirmed by a second consecutive assessment. Radiographic progression in bone was based on The Prostate Cancer Clinical Trials Working Group (PCWG2) guidelines defined as at least 2 new lesions on bone scan. Radiographic progression in soft tissue on Computerized Tomography/Magnetic Resonance Imaging (CT/MRI) was based on Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST 1.1). CT/MRI and bone scans were read locally by the same radiologist (or nuclear medicine physician for interpretation of bone scans) whenever possible. Participants not known to have had a PFS event at the time of the analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last assessment.
measure.population: Intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment.

measurement_list.measurement: The upper limit of the 95% confidence interval was not available because an insufficient number of participants had an event at the time of analysis.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value based on log-rank test stratified by disease stage at study entry as reported on the case report form (CRF).
analysis.estimate_desc: Hazard ratio is based on a Cox regression model (with treatment as the only covariate) stratified by disease stage at study entry and is relative to bicalutamide with < 1 favoring enzalutamide.

outcome.title: Time to PSA Progression
outcome.description: PSA progression was defined as ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir and was to be confirmed by a second consecutive assessment at least 3 weeks later. Participants not known to have had PSA progression were censored at the date of last PSA assessment.
outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
outcome.population: Intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

measure.title: Time to PSA Progression
measure.description: PSA progression was defined as ≥ 25% increase in PSA with an absolute increase ≥ 2 ng/mL above the nadir and was to be confirmed by a second consecutive assessment at least 3 weeks later. Participants not known to have had PSA progression were censored at the date of last PSA assessment.
measure.population: Intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment.

measurement_list.measurement: The median time to PSA progression and its upper limit of the 95% confidence interval were not available because an insufficient number of participants had an event at the time of analysis.

analysis.p_value_desc: P-value based on log-rank test stratified by disease stage at study entry as reported on the CRF.
analysis.estimate_desc: Hazard ratio is based on a Cox regression model (with treatment as the only covariate) stratified by disease stage at study entry and is relative to bicalutamide with < 1 favoring enzalutamide.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With a PSA Response ≥ 50%
outcome.description: PSA response was defined as a reduction in PSA of at least 50% from baseline at any postbaseline assessment confirmed by a second PSA assessment at least 3 weeks later.
outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
outcome.population: Evaluable intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment and had a baseline and at least 1 postbaseline PSA measurement.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With a PSA Response ≥ 50%
measure.description: PSA response was defined as a reduction in PSA of at least 50% from baseline at any postbaseline assessment confirmed by a second PSA assessment at least 3 weeks later.
measure.population: Evaluable intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment and had a baseline and at least 1 postbaseline PSA measurement.

analysis.method_desc: Comparison of the 2 treatment groups using the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel mean score test stratified by disease stage at study entry.
analysis.estimate_desc: Enzalutamide response rate minus bicalutamide response rate.

outcome.title: Duration of Radiographic PFS
outcome.description: Duration of radiographic PFS was defined as the time from randomization to the earliest objective evidence of radiographic disease progression or death on study and was to be evaluated for participants with metastatic disease at study entry. Radiographic disease progression in bone was based on PCWG2 guidelines defined as at least 2 new lesions on bone scan. Radiographic disease progression in soft tissue on CT/MRI was based on RECIST 1.1. CT/MRI and bone scans were read locally by the same radiologist (or nuclear medicine physician for interpretation of bone scans) whenever possible. Participants not known to have had radiographic progression at the time of analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last radiographic assessment.
outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
outcome.population: All participants with metastatic disease at study entry and randomly assigned to study treatment.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

measure.title: Duration of Radiographic PFS
measure.description: Duration of radiographic PFS was defined as the time from randomization to the earliest objective evidence of radiographic disease progression or death on study and was to be evaluated for participants with metastatic disease at study entry. Radiographic disease progression in bone was based on PCWG2 guidelines defined as at least 2 new lesions on bone scan. Radiographic disease progression in soft tissue on CT/MRI was based on RECIST 1.1. CT/MRI and bone scans were read locally by the same radiologist (or nuclear medicine physician for interpretation of bone scans) whenever possible. Participants not known to have had radiographic progression at the time of analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last radiographic assessment.
measure.population: All participants with metastatic disease at study entry and randomly assigned to study treatment.

measurement_list.measurement: The median duration of radiographic PFS and its upper limit of the 95% confidence interval were not available because an insufficient number of participants had an event at the time of analysis.

analysis.method_desc: P-value is based on an unstratified log-rank test.
analysis.estimate_desc: Hazard ratio is based on an unstratified Cox-regression model (with treatment as the only covariate) and is relative to bicalutamide with < 1 favoring enzalutamide.

outcome.title: Quality of Life: Time to Degradation of Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Prostate (FACT-P)
outcome.description: The FACT-P is a multidimensional, self-reported quality of life instrument consisting of 27 core items that assess patient function in 4 domains: physical, social/family, emotional, and functional well-being, and supplemented by 12 site-specific items to assess for prostate-related symptoms. Each item is rated on a 0 to 4 Likert-type scale, and then combined to produce subscale scores for each domain, as well as a global quality of life score (0 to 156) with higher scores representing better quality of life. Time to degradation of FACT-P was defined as the time from randomization to first assessment with at least a 10-point decrease from baseline in the global FACT-P score for each participant. Participants with no score degradation at the time of analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last assessment showing no degradation.
outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
outcome.population: Intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

measure.title: Quality of Life: Time to Degradation of Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Prostate (FACT-P)
measure.description: The FACT-P is a multidimensional, self-reported quality of life instrument consisting of 27 core items that assess patient function in 4 domains: physical, social/family, emotional, and functional well-being, and supplemented by 12 site-specific items to assess for prostate-related symptoms. Each item is rated on a 0 to 4 Likert-type scale, and then combined to produce subscale scores for each domain, as well as a global quality of life score (0 to 156) with higher scores representing better quality of life. Time to degradation of FACT-P was defined as the time from randomization to first assessment with at least a 10-point decrease from baseline in the global FACT-P score for each participant. Participants with no score degradation at the time of analysis data cutoff were censored at the date of last assessment showing no degradation.
measure.population: Intent-to-treat population: all participants randomly assigned to study treatment.

analysis.p_value_desc: This secondary endpoint was not adjusted for multiple comparisons.
analysis.method_desc: P-value is based on a log-rank test stratified by disease stage at study entry.
analysis.estimate_desc: Hazard ratio is based on a Cox regression model (with treatment as the only covariate) stratified by disease stage at study entry and is relative to bicalutamide with < 1 favoring enzalutamide.

outcome.title: Best Overall Soft Tissue Response
outcome.description: Best overall soft tissue response is defined as partial response (PR) or complete response (CR) while on study treatment based on investigator assessment of target, nontarget, and new lesions using RECIST 1.1. Only participants in the metastatic population with measurable soft tissue disease (at least 1 target lesion identified per RECIST 1.1) at screening were included in the analysis. All percentages are based on number of participants with metastatic and measurable soft tissue disease at screening in each treatment group.
outcome.time_frame: From randomization until the data cut-off date of 09 February 2015, median duration of treatment was 14.7 months in the enzalutamide arm and 8.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
outcome.population: All participants who were randomly assigned to study treatment and had metastatic and measurable soft tissue disease at screening.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants randomized to receive bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

measure.title: Best Overall Soft Tissue Response
measure.description: Best overall soft tissue response is defined as partial response (PR) or complete response (CR) while on study treatment based on investigator assessment of target, nontarget, and new lesions using RECIST 1.1. Only participants in the metastatic population with measurable soft tissue disease (at least 1 target lesion identified per RECIST 1.1) at screening were included in the analysis. All percentages are based on number of participants with metastatic and measurable soft tissue disease at screening in each treatment group.
measure.population: All participants who were randomly assigned to study treatment and had metastatic and measurable soft tissue disease at screening.

analysis.p_value_desc: This secondary endpoint was not adjusted for multiple comparisons.
analysis.method_desc: Based on unstratified Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel mean score test.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Adverse Event (AE)
outcome.time_frame: From first dose of study drug up to 30 days after last dose of study drug. Median duration of the AE reporting period was 15.2 months in the enzalutamide arm and 9.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
outcome.population: Safety population: All participants randomly assigned to study treatment who received at least 1 dose of study drug.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants received bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Adverse Event (AE)
measure.population: Safety population: All participants randomly assigned to study treatment who received at least 1 dose of study drug.

class.title: AE leading to study drug discontinuation
Serious AE related to study drug

reported_events.time_frame: From first dose of study drug up to 30 days after last dose of study drug. Median duration of the AE reporting period was 15.2 months in the enzalutamide arm and 9.4 months in the bicalutamide arm.
reported_events.desc: Adverse event collection began at the time of first dose of study drug and continued through 30 days after the last dose of study drug. The participant was questioned in a general way and no specific symptoms were suggested.

group.title: Enzalutamide
group.description: Participants received enzalutamide 160 mg, self-administered as four 40-mg capsules, once per day by mouth and 1 bicalutamide-placebo capsule.

group.title: Bicalutamide
group.description: Participants received bicalutamide 50 mg, self-administered as 1 capsule, once per day by mouth and 4 enzalutamide-placebo capsules.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: PI agrees not to independently publish the results before the publication of the multi-center PI paper. Sponsor shall review and comment 30 days prior to submission or disclosure. If publication or disclosure contains Sponsor Confidential Information, other than study data, PI agrees to remove Confidential Information from publication or disclosure. Sponsor may request that PI delay such publication for an additional 60 days to protect the patentability of any invention described.
